snippet: Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010.

headline.main: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry

snippet: Full planes make it worthwhile to vie for priority seating and other preferential treatment.
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on whether it is worthwhile, in an era of packed airplanes, to get credit cards that are linked to airlines that would qualify him for extra miles or elite status and allow him preferential boarding treatment.

headline.main: Selling Boarding Perks to the Forlorn

snippet: A company that sells video calling services finds that people with iPhones are four times more likely to spend money on apps than people with Android phones are.

snippet: The headquarters of the start-up Square would be the absolute worst place to play hide-and-seek. There are no offices. Executives sit in open cubicles. All of the conference rooms, large and small, are surrounded by walls of clear glass. The only ...
abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column notes Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey is now working on Square, a mobile payment system; says Dorsey believes the clear glass and open spaces of his San Francisco office will build the trust and transparency the company must cultivate to succeed. (M)

headline.main: Disruptions: Design Sets the Tone At a Place Called Square
